title: What single piece of infrastructure would cause the most chaos if it just suddenly stopped working right now? - Quora

response.answer_text: “In reality, technology not only enables so much of our daily lives, but we've become dependent on it to the extent that small technological glitches can result in massive system failures. Even when it isn't the result of an attack or data breach, the results can be crippling.” “Most of the time, we don't think about technology, since most of the time it just works. No one expects to show up at a store and be unable to make purchases. The same thing is true for the power grid, mobile phones, and the internet. We just expect them to work because most of the time, they do.” “In reality, however, the infrastructure that makes it work is actually quite fragile. Most of our daily lives depends on interconnected pieces of hardware, all of which run sophisticated software code. While many of the most critical pieces have backups and redundancy, that isn't always the case.” Target Suffers Pair of Outages and It's a Reminder We're All Just 1 Technology Fail Away From Chaos

Communications, with respect to some other well thought out answers, I believe this to be the #1 best answer. Without communications all other infrastructure fails. Not only do they fail, they don't get repaired because without communications no one is assigned to repair them or even informed of the various failures. Without communications people start to do what they think is best. That is the very definition of chaos because there would exist no uniformity of purpose or action. Removing communications gets rid of any solidarity of purpose or direction.

Clean running water. People would start dying within days. Especially in cities where there is no access to fresh water nearby. If they ive in apartments or condos they have no way to safely bury or otherwise dispose of human waste. Without clean water to wash with infections and diseases will spread quickly.

Electric grid. That takes out water and sewage in the cities once the backup generators run it of fuel. It takes out fuel refineries, which takes out the trucking industry and diesel trains. That takes out food deliveries, bottled water delivery, and any thing else that relies on transport.
Nuclear power plants. Can you imagine hundreds of meltdowns around the world at the same time? Hundreds of chernobyls and fukushimas? Look up “Life after people”
Roads. If there were no paved roads all transportation of food, supplies, and individuals would stop. Bad Juju. YMMV
